awd_titl_txt: US Participation at the Twenty-fifth International Domain Decomposition Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The 25th International Domain Decomposition Conference (DD25) will be held at the Memorial University of Newfoundland in St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada, during July 23-27, 2018. The conference website is http://dd25.math.mun.ca/index.html . The conference will be comprised of mini-symposia and contributed talks, along with thirteen invited talks.

Domain decomposition methods are fundamental to large scale high performance computing in the sciences and engineering. The International Domain Decomposition Conference, which has been held approximately every eighteen months since 1987, is the preeminent conference in domain decomposition methods that brings together mathematicians, engineers, and scientists to exchange information and ideas on the latest cutting-edge developments in the field. This funding will provide travel costs for young US participants, graduate students, and recent Ph.D. recipients, to learn about recent developments in domain decomposition and to interact with renowned international experts in computational engineering and computational sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Today's simulation based research in science and engineering relies
heavily on high performance computing, where the computation is often
carried out on supercomputers with over a hundred thousand processors.
Domain decomposition methods, which divide the computational task
associated with a large computational domain into more manageable problems
on subdomains, provide one of the most natural and successful approaches
that enables large scale computations to be performed on parallel
computers. The International Domain Decomposition Conference, launched in
1987, is the preeminent conference series in this research area that
brings together mathematicians, engineers and scientists to exchange
information and ideas on the latest cutting-edge developments.

This grant provided partial support for ten junior US participants to
attend the Twenty-fifth International Domain Decomposition Conference
(DD25) at the Memorial University in St. John's, Newfoundland, Canada
during July 23-27, 2018. This diverse group, consisting of seven graduate
students and three recent Ph.D. recipients, includes three females and two
Hispanic males.  Their participation in this prestigious conference
strengthens the pipeline for young talent that will become the next
generation researchers in this important area.

Information about this very successful conference can be found at
https://dd25.math.mun.ca/

A proceedings volume for this conference is in preparation.
Details will be announced at www.ddm.org

Last Modified: 06/24/2019
Modified by: Susanne C Brenner
